questions.correct_answer: In a regular polygon with odd sides, there is no vertex directly opposite to any vertex. Therefore, each line of symmetry must pass through a vertex and the midpoint of the opposite side to maintain equal division.
questions.question_text: Explain why a regular polygon with an odd number of sides has all its lines of symmetry passing through a vertex and the midpoint of the opposite side.

questions.correct_answer: (a) A'(2, 2), B'(6, 2), C'(4, 5) (b) Yes, reflection preserves size and shape, creating congruent figures.

questions.correct_answer: (a) The shape returns to its original position. (b) The identity transformation (no change).

questions.correct_answer: M' coincides with M (same position). Since M is on the mirror line, it is equidistant (distance = 0) from both sides of the line, so its reflection is itself.
